title: Pensioners are £9 a week better off than those in work
text:

Wed, Oct 21, 2015, 19:26 BST - UK Markets closed Pensioners are £9 a week better off than those in work By Dan Hyde | Telegraph – 23 hours ago 0.00 0.00 
For the first time, the retired have a larger weekly income on average than those of working age, as some call for an end to generous increases to state pensions 
Pensioners now enjoy larger weekly incomes than people of working age after an "astonishing turnaround" in poverty among the elderly, analysis of average pay shows for the first time. 
The Institute for Fiscal Studies said the generosity of work pensions, better state support and the diligence of the baby boomer generation in paying off mortgages had made the retired "better off than ever before". 
Its research showed on average pensioners earn £394 a week compared to the £385 median among the working age population. 
The influential think tank said the figures represented a "remarkable" transformation from the state of affairs in 1990, when pensioners were around 30 per cent poorer than those in work. 
• Britain's biggest pension funds 'deliberately' delaying freedoms 
Such has been advance in the wealth among older people in the past 25 years that four in 10 households now earn more from pensions than they did on average during their working lives. 
However, the IFS warned that pensioner wealth would collapse again in a decade due to the financial pressures on younger generations. 
As well as failing to get on the property ladder, many of those under 50 will be without the generous "final salary" pensions their retired parents currently collect. Such schemes have been replaced with stock-market linked pensions, which tend to offer poorer value. 
Paul Johnson, director of the organisation, also predicted that the Government would be forced to pare back increases to the state pension , which was becoming "prohibitively expensive". 
"We have achieved an astonishing turnaround in the incomes of pensioners over the last three decades, without increasing public spending to levels seen in many other continental European countries," Mr Johnson told a conference last night. 
"But the longer term future looks very uncertain. Those now in their 20s, 30s and 40s may well end up with lower incomes in retirement than their parents." 
The comparisons between working age and pensioner incomes were made after tax, housing costs and benefits such as the state pension. 
Mr Johnson urged the Government to abandon its flagship "triple lock" that guarantees the state pension rises in value every 12 months . 
Introduced in 2010, the policy increases the weekly payout, currently £115.95, by the higher of inflation on the consumer prices index, average earnings growth or 2.5 per cent. 
Britain's top pension funds ranked by their place in a study of the world’s 300 largest pension schemes : 
In January, David Cameron pledged that the Conservatives would keep the measure as it brought "dignity" to those in old age. 
"People who have worked hard, who have done the right thing, who have provided for their families, they should then know they will get a decent state pension and they don't have to worry about it lagging behind prices or earnings and I think that's the right choice for the country," he said. 
But Mr Johnson said the cost of the policy, compared with only uprating pensions in line with the earnings of the wider workforce, would within five decades reach "well over £20 billion a year" in today’s terms - equal to 1.3 per cent of GDP. 
"The triple lock policy needs to end," Mr Johnson said. "At some point it will prove to be prohibitively expensive." 
He said the qualifying age, scheduled to reach 66 for both men and women by 2020, would have to rise significantly, forcing younger people to work longer for the same money as their parents. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) was vital, he added, that the Government resisted the urge to conduct a tax raid on pensions as part of a major consultation that began in July. The Treasury has indicated that it could treat money paid into a pension more like an Isa, offering tax free withdrawal. 
The guaranteed incomes (annuities) savers can buy with private sector pensions are becoming less valuable: 
Mr Johnson said savers should continue to be rewarded with tax incentives when they put money into a pension . 
"There is an urgent need to bring stability and rationality to the taxation of private pensions," he said. "Changes have been made far too frequently, making long-term planning impossible." 
"Its starting point ought to be that providing people with tax relief for pension saving when contributions are made, and charging tax (including National Insurance) on withdrawal, is the efficient, neutral basis for personal taxation."
